post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: Fourier Transfrom is the same as Z-transform, but restricted to $$\vert z\vert =1$$.

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: The reason is the restriction on the choice of z in Fourier Transform.  In Z-transform, there is no restriction on z.  In Fourier transform, however, we restrict it to unit circle.

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: I guess that this has to do with the type of signal that is being sampled.  Suppose that the signal under consideration is completely random and that we know nothing about it.  Then we have no option but to sample at a very high rate.  Then, it does not matter how you sample, random sampling may do.  But if you know something about the signal and you want to minimise the sampling rate, you would want to use some logic - random sampling does not seem to be the right choice.

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: Chronologically, what you say is correct.  Using the maximum value of F, we decide Fs.  On the other hand, when we do a thought experiment, we can do the opposite.  This helps discuss the following issue: Given a nominal value of F, Fs is selected and fixed.  If now F changes, how it will affect the sampling process?  A similar kind of procedure will be followed in control system design also.

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: This is a symmetric choice.  Moreover, as shown in Slide 31, using the properties of odd and even functions, we need to carry out the calculations for only half the $$\omega$$ values.  This cannot be done if you use arbitrary domain.

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: You will first have to divide the numerator by the denominator and bring it to the form $$K + \frac {B(z)}{A(z)}$$, with the fraction being strictly proper.  One can then apply the partial fraction expansion techniques to the second term, B/A.

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: It depends on ROC.  If the ROC is the same for both $$U_1$$ and $$U_2$$, then the implication you have suggested is true.  But if the ROCs are different, the time domain signals can be different, even if their Z-transforms are identical.  This is explained in Section 4.1.2 of the book, the tile of the section being "Absolute Convergence".

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: No that is not the main reason for the development of Z-transform.  Fourier transform is defined only for bounded signals.  This restriction is not there in case of Z-transforms.  This is important because we have to deal with unbounded signals also in control applications.

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response

post.subject: Re: 24 Jan. 2013 - 4: Inv. Z-Transform and Frequency Response
post.message: Yes, express the input using Fourier series.  Apply the principle of frequency response to every element of Fourier series.  Finally, apply the superposition principle.
